sammiluvsmusic: Bless this woman...I am from South India, and my skin to is considered dark. I never understood that because I thought dark skinned people had superpowers! Because we didn't get skin burnt when we were in the skin. We didn't get melanoma that easily, compared to the pale counterparts. However, my family (not my immediate family) made sure NY confidence went down. One time, my aunt took me to this beauty lady and she used this face mask...with slight traces of bleach in it. Luckily, nothing happened to my skin...idk what I would've done of something did happen. I was only a child. I had to have several years of growth to get to the fact that I am freaking awesome, and freaking gorgeous. This was a tough story to share...so I am glad this mother helped this little girl so early. I hope she grows up to be a well stabeled, balanced, confident woman who doesn't give a shit.

zaraeve: When I was very young my aunt would visit from Europe and would always comment on the colour of my skin, how dark I was, how ugly I was, and unfortunately my mum never stood up or defended me or explained to me that skin colour didn’t matter. It wasn’t actually till just a couple of weeks ago that I day my mum down and told her how that affected me and how her not defending me made me feel like my aunt was right. I am determined to make sure that no kid in my life ever has to feel that way and that they all know how amazing and beautiful they are just as themselves.

linawilkins_: As an apparently dark Indian girl.. this was so beautiful to see and hear.. and to know this still exists.. 🙈😅
archie_mup: My sister has lighter skin and i am dark. We are eight years apart. I am the baby of my house. Growing up everybody used to compare our skin tones and talk openly about how beautiful my sister is and how lucky she is for her lighter skin tone. I always thought i was the uggo of my house. When i was about 5 years old I remember My sister telling me that ‘people who are born dark become lighter after growing up and people who are born lighter get darker growing up’ just to make me happy. She used to fight with her friends and cut ties with anyone who compared our skin tones. She always used to protect me. At age 10 i was convinced that i could never be beautiful and i would rather be successful to have a chance in this society, so I studied hard and kept sailing through comments about my skin tone. I was told that i have really good features and if only my skin was lighter i had a chance in life. Imagine hearing these sort of comments at a tender age of 5 or 6. It sure is the worst trauma for a little girl. When i turned 18 i had a lot of boys following me around. I never understood what they saw in me because i was convinced that i was ugly. I moved to the US at 21 and white men asked me out for dates and i slowly started to realize that I wasn’t ugly and my color was not a barrier for my beauty. I has this sudden aura of realization that dark is beautiful too. That was my little story growing up. Watching this video brought back my childhood memories. Indian society is harsh on darker skin tones specially for women. When i was in India last summer i was looking to buy a simple moisturizer in a market. To my horror every product in the market including soaps were ‘fairness’ enhancing. Really frustrating to see that. Pretty sure there are thousands of little girls who are already convinced that they are ugly just because they are dark. This has to stop. I love how live tinted represents all shades of beauty. Big fan of the product and @deepica.

mwapemiller: It hurts seeing this because my niece used to wish to look like the white kids in her school she is darker skinned, but so beautiful, we are African, and my mum is Zambian and my dad Moroccan. I'm really light my mum and I came out the lightest in our whole family and I had issues with being so fair while my whole family had this gorgeous medium dark to really dark brown skin and when my niece was born and I was her main child care giver after school and weekends from ages 3 to just before lockdown, I would always tell her how gorgeous she is and how she has her beautiful afro hair that everybody loves with the amazing styles she can have it in and everyone wishes they could do with theirs and her gorgeous eyes and such a heart warming smile and she truly now loves herself! She once asked me why I was white with a bush on my head like hers n all I could say is because God made me like this and we are the same brown people just I came out light and she came out darker and my bro who is her dad is darker than me too, so i just showed her all the ranges of beauty in the different shades of black there is! The majority of her friends in school were white so she used to wish for long, straight, blonde hair, so I would wear mine out to show her how beautiful natural is, till she got it and she loves hers now! Our brown and black babies need to hear this so much, it hurts so much seeing n hearing those words from this gorgeous child on the video, she is stunning! It took my nieces questioning to make me accept myself being so light too. I used to think light skin was ugly because I hated being the one which could pass for almost white. Colourism is so bad in my culture thankfully brown and black women are beginning to realise that black is beautiful! xxx❤️😘

thecultcurators: This is such an important video - because it shows how early the conditioning sets in and because it shows how each one of us can help change/alter that! anaghavinayak: The most beautiful thing on the internet today❤️
have_faith18: First of all... SHES GORGEOUS!! Periodt!! 😍😍❤️❤️. Shine sis!! Second of all, colorism is one of the most divisive elements in a community. I am African American (African by birth, who is now in America) and it just boggles my mind how such a simple thing as skin tone can affect how people treat you, what men find attractive, what the media praises, and even what makeup companies produce. Sometimes I ask myself, “how is this my problem?” And then I realize the systemic poison that had been fed for hundreds of years during slavery and the preferences for the children born out of rape and later on consensual mixed race coupling. Our natural hair and skin was ugly, unless it was mixed with something lighter, which gave us a sense of worth and beauty. It’s so stupid and so simple (as in simple Simon stupid), but then the impact it has on young girls especially, who are singled out even by their own families. It’s difficult enough going out into the world and the world telling and showing you that you’re “too dark,” or “pretty for a dark skinned girl.” It’s just so sickening and sad that this lie has spread across many cultures, but I’m glad that there are platforms such as this one that praises “tinted” girls and their beauty. Please, tell your daughters that they’re beautiful, stand up for them if anyone challenges that (including family and friends), let them know whoever thinks their skin tone diminishes their worth is not worth their time. And don’t laugh at cheap jokes make about them too because those cut deep. And lastly, grow up people because, as a dark skinned angel, this is getting old and tiring and just plain stupid.

bryan_kayj: I have grown up being bullied because of my skin colour. Think of adults in the family itself who start it and so does your little cousin. And when i got into high school it was worst. Imagine being bullied for being dark, for talking through the nose,having curly hair. But being bullied for my skin color, had a long term toll on my self esteem. I even left a highly reputed school and move to a private school because everyday I was called charcoal and dusters were being blown on my face (pretending they didn’t see me since i was dark) as well as being rejected for being a cheerleader for sports days as a girl came up and told me I am dark and not beautiful to do so. I had even just posted my experience on a post in my account about all these. And all these led to me having Red Skin today because I used steroid creams to get fairer. But I realize that there is more to skin color. I am recovering from Steroid withdrawal symptoms and brown and dark with pigmentations is beautiful because that’s me. Dark skin and every other shades are beautiful. 🤎

damalirai: South Asians have some of the richest and most divine skin tones I’ve seen! I pray we see a change in the way we view skin color. This baby has skin that was kissed by God! @deepica
nickivashi: @deepica if I’m not wrong this isn’t her mom speaking to her it’s @thelifeofasocialbutterfly herself. Just thought I’d let you know 🙂. Anyways such a relevant topic and it’s so important that we encourage children to realise they’re beautiful in any form ! 😍
